data.text: Anyone Still Using Toe Clips?
How many are still using toe clips? This is a recent photo of a user I used ‘em until I discovered clipless about 10 years ago Much safer option
I move from clipless to clipped in 1986. Never looked back.
data.author: Steve Perkins

data.text: Since invention of clipless pedals only place for this are vintage bikes.
data.author: Rok Pajer

data.text: "Clipless" isn't really. SPD's and other pedals that retain a shoe cleat have clips. They just aren't toe clips. I have been clipping into SPD's for 30 years and never looked back on toe clips. They anchor my foot exactly where it needs to be on the pedal and make my life easer.
data.author: Chris Balduc

data.text: I’m a toe clip user on my bikes.
data.author: Kathy Mehrzad

data.text: I use toe clips. It allows you to ride with any type of shoe. I would think that the majority of tourers actually don't use toe clips.

data.text: My dad is a toe clip user!

data.text: I still use them and love them.

data.text: I still use them, partly because I like them and partly because the clips on my touring bike are so old that I can’t get them off the bike.

data.text: I went back to toe clips, the strapless kind, after overbalancing at a stop light, on a loaded bike, in front of a car. Not good. Pedalling up steep grades with SPDs, when I might grind to a halt at any time, also seemed quite foolhardy.

data.text: Me, I like them.

data.text: WHAT ARE THOOOOSE!? 😅

data.text: I use MTB-style half clips. They're effortless to get in and out of, I can't get stuck in them, they keep my feet securely on the pedals in the rain, they don't have any sharp edges to claw up my legs, I can wear any shoes I want, I can bring my pedal up to my preferred starting position just by lifting my foot.

I always ride with clipless, but this is an interesting video on the topic: https://youtu.be/KUEaN9FKGLE
Are Clipless Pedals Actually More Efficient Than Flat Pedals? The Answer Might Surprise You.

I'm not a biker really, but I can't remember a time in my life where my feet slip off the pedals... so I think I'm just going to go with flat for the trip!

data.text: yessss! I was beginning to think that I was the only one who prefers flat pedals!

data.text: Need solid soled shoes that don’t flex n you’re golden
data.author: Joseph Long

data.text: I have them on my touring and my road bikes - but a firmer, shorter version that does not require the straps. I have been using them for the past 14 years since first coming across them whilst in Switzerland. I can wear any footwear from flipflops to my heavy winter boots with them - love having them.
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: I used Crank Brother Egg Betters and then Candies but now clips without straps and Keen Newport Sandals. They are for me the perfect combination especially for touring. With socks when it’s cool without when it’s hot and quick drying when it’s wet.

Joe Calamia

data.text: I used to use Power Grips. Now my daily ride is a cyclo cross bike with mountain flats pedals. I can’t believe the staff put President Biden on anything except flat pedals!
data.author: David Gruberg

data.text: This video begins with an incorrect hypothesis. The main benefit of clipless pedals is not and never has been the added ability of "pulling up." As the video states in a roundabout manner, our leg muscles are not designed to pull up well. The benefit of clipless pedals and that of the older toe clips comes from the position of the foot on the pedal. By keeping the foot positioned so that the metatarsal arch is positioned over the pedal axle and the foot is at the correct angle the rider can apply the maximum power to the pedal without any additional effort. If you must use muscle movement to keep repositioning the foot on the pedal you are using the power that is not popeling the bike forward. A component of the toe clip, which is not discussed in most of these anti-clipless pedal arguments, is the cleat that was nailed to the sole of cycling shoes of the day. The cleat helped in maintaining the correct angle of the foot on the pedal as clipless pedals do today. The angle of the foot is very important in preventing knee and leg problems from the application of power without proper alignment of the joints. One of the major benefits of a professional bike fit is the correct foot/pedal position for maximum application of power.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: Only on my Peloton. On any bike that actually moves, mountain bike flats.

data.text: Yes. That’s all I use. They’re far better than clipless IMO.

data.text: For commuting, just the clips can be more useful (as opposed to the clips and straps) than clipless. It allows you to wear normal shoes and keeps you from sliding forward off the pedal if rain occurs.

data.text: Yep... After 50+ years of cycling I wouldn't use anything else 😉 Why fix it if it ain't broke😉

data.text: I've been riding/racing for 30 years. Mtn dh, xc, ds...tris, crits, gran fundos.... just did an 800mi in Europe last year and a fully supported 700mi just now in italy.... for touring, there is nothing better than crank bros pedals combined with their mallet boa shoes. Nothing. If you want to step that up a notch get their double sideed and bring sandals.

data.text: There should be an executive order banning those things.
data.author: Ryan Cappo

data.text: No need now that I am 64 yrs old. I used clipless on my road bike & liked them. But now I don’t own a road bike & gone electric. No toe clips either, need easy on & off. No need for speed anymore!

data.text: My older bikes have toe clips and I feel safer and more comfortable in them than being clipped in but it may be due to my age.

data.text: I use them - on a very long and hot tour day I was soooo tired that I simply forgot to unclip and almost fell directly into the path of oncoming traffic. As soon as I got home I switched to toe clips.

data.text: I used to love toe clips! I restored an early 80s bike a couple years ago, and wanted to keep it "stock," so I left the quill pedals with toe clips on for a couple rides. Hah! What a pain in the butt! I never fell, but it required too much concentration to overcome muscle memory from using SPD clipless pedals, especially if I'd tightened the straps. I don't know how I did this so fluidly back in the day! :)

data.text: For touring, SPD with mtb shoes is the way to go. I can unclip in one millisecond. The cage style is too dangerous -- takes too long to get your foot free.

data.author: Mike Michon

data.text: The reason the president fell was because he wore wide tread running sneakers on his bicycle with narrow road pedals fitted with clips and straps. The oversized rubber tread of that type of shoe is more likely to get hung up on the strap resulting in embarrassment or injury. It's safer to use very wide pedals such as touring "rat traps" or mtb "bear traps" if you insist on cycling in sneakers. Otherwise wear a shoe that fits snug with a very minimal sole, like old school leather touring shoes.

data.text: I’m old school and non-techie. (I don’t even know what “SPD” is:)). I use ‘cages’ like the ones pictured on both my road and Salsa Cutthroat bikes. I love them, never had a problem and I know plenty of people who have had accidents while “clipped in.” I figure I’m not fast enough anyway to gain any benefit from “clipping in.” (The terminology on all this makes no sense, IMO).
